Replace.Text: For this Age, gain +15% Food[icon:YIELD_FOOD] at the cost of -10% Gold[icon:YIELD_GOLD]
For this Age, +3 Combat Strength for your Naval Units at the cost of -10% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY]
For this Age, gain +15% Food[icon:YIELD_FOOD] at the cost of -10% Gold[icon:YIELD_GOLD]
For this Age, +3 Combat Strength for your Air Units at the cost of -10% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY]
Legend Unlock. +50% [icon:YIELD_GOLD]Gold towards converting a Town to a City.
Legend Unlock. +5 Combat Strength for all Units against Districts.

Simón Bolívar led the movements that would result in the independence of South America from Spain, and as such was dubbed “El Libertador,” the Liberator, for his efforts. While in-fighting between other would-be leaders and Bolívar fragmented his idea of a unified South America, he struck a decisive blow to European control over the continent, and remains revered as a hero today.

He was born in Venezuela to a wealthy criollo family (having European ancestry) in 1783. Thrust into stewardship of his family’s estate and wealth as a child, he also educated himself on the principles of liberty coming out of France at the time, and was influenced greatly by Jean-Jacques Rousseau. As a young man, he witnessed Napoleon’s rise to power during a visit to Paris. He admired Napoleon’s accomplishments, but was repelled by such intense consolidation of power in the wake of the Revolution.

As the Napoleonic wars sapped France’s strength (and, by extension, that of its Spanish puppet state), the junta in Caracas declared independence. In the subsequent conflicts, where Venezuela would become liberated and fall again to Spain, Bolívar found himself moving from rallying troops to rallying diplomatic support. In one memorable moment, he marched his troops across the Andes in a brutal trek, to eventually catch the Spanish off-guard and sweep downwards from the heights to victory.

In the landscape that came after independence, Bolívar struggled to keep some degree of unity. In this endeavor, he clashed with his vice president, Francisco de Paula Santander, over the relative values of democracy and unity. Bolívar sought a lifetime presidency, and a stronger hand on the reins of power, whereas Santander had a vision of electoral democracy. Eventually, Bolívar declared himself dictator, but found himself deposed only two years afterwards.

Tubercular and with his hopes for a united South America on shaky ground, Bolívar sought to travel to Europe, but died in 1830. He had liberated the continent, but likened the struggle to an attempt to “plow the sea.” His legacy forever remains enshrined in South America as a monument to revolution.
It is harder to maintain the balance of liberty than to endure the weight of tyranny.
I am Simón Bolívar, the hand that crushes tyranny and leads nations to liberty.
I am Simón Bolívar, the hand that crushes tyranny and leads nations to liberty.
I am Simón Bolívar, the hand that crushes tyranny and leads nations to liberty.
You are a monster infesting this earth, and your punishment will equal your crimes.
You, aged serpent, will not swallow my land to satisfy your venomous rage.
I have seen the light. Now I fall back into darkness.
You honor me with such a thrilling proposition.
Your ideas are well-meaning but misguided.
Gain 1 free Support on your wars. When you conquer a Settlement for the first time it can purchase 1 Constructible for free. Unrest does not prevent Purchasing.

[LIST][LI]Gain [b]1 free Support[/b] on your wars. [LI]When you conquer a Settlement for the first time the Settlement can [b]purchase 1 Constructible for free[/b]. [LI]Unrest does not prevent Purchasing. [/LIST]
Likes the Leader with the least Unhappy Settlements. Dislikes the one with the most Unhappy Settlements.

As the Napoleonic Wars weakened Spain’s presence in the Americas, Simón Bolívar, "El Libertador," led forces to liberate the region. With tenacity and charisma, he led his armies to victory, and the people to independence. The instability of newfound freedom proved difficult to overcome. First president and then dictator of Gran Colombia, he failed to fully enact his ambitions. Yet Bolívar remains an enduring example of South American defiance.
+20%[icon:YIELD_FOOD] Food when in only one Alliance.
+1[icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness per Age on Military Buildings.
+50%[icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold towards purchasing Units during a Celebration.

Contains a new Leader, Simón Bolívar.
Bolívar has seen the care with which the library's keepers handles the collected wisdom of these times, yet still he wishes to ensure that it does not waste away in cold cellars.
Surrounded by throngs of adoring subjects, Bolívar cannot help being swept up in the moment. A crown newly gracing his head, the sight of Emperor Napoleon is seared into Bolívar's memory.
His military cunning knows no equal.
This is not the same resplendent emperor Bolívar saw on that fateful coronation day. Was it all just a show?
One by one, Bolívar's commanders don decorations in acknowledgement of their bravery, their dedication to the cause of freedom.
It is an inspiration to other soldiers.
It is an inspiration to all.
Simón Bolívar stands among the fields that blanket his lands and feed his people, the grain shimmering from a recent rainfall.
These lands are just the beginning.
With Bolívar's encouragement, his people seek out new lands to settle and work. In time, lifegiving rains will grace them as well.
Bolívar walks the length of the ramparts, granting him a new perspective on his empire. His lands still stretch as far as he can see, but now their heart is defended.
Bolívar's merchants meet their neighbors at the bargaining table, looking for a deal that will line their pockets with gold.
Remember the farmer, the miner, the stablehand.
Bolívar's empire is not a place, but a people — the merchant, the soldier, the laborer alike.
Have a Settlement with 10 Rural Population.
The dust of battle clears, settling on the defeated and the victors both. Bolívar's soldiers stow their weapons, and wait for his command to draw them again.
Bolívar calls for an end to the bloodshed, with {1_STORY_CITY} under the firm control of his lieutenants. He can send no clearer message to his enemies.
Bolívar acknowledges {1_Independent} and sees a free, independent people. But whose freedom is more important?
Bolívar acknowledges {1_Independent} and sees a free, independent people. First impressions are paramount.
After a hard and bloody battle, Bolívar's troops retake {1_STORY_CITY}, {2_civilization_adj} citizens cheering as the Spanish conquerors are taken prisoner. It is a good day.
Free Promotion on highest Level Commander.
Bolívar is forced to flee to {1_capital}, the fate of his country hanging in the balance. In the face of death, he searches for the correct response.
+1 War Support on all wars but a Building becomes Pillaged in {1_capital}.
Bolívar nods to the crowds as he makes his triumphant return to {1_capital}. They are once again — no, they have always been — {2_civilization_adj} people.
A thousand times a day, Bolívar's aides come to him for guidance and instruction, be it on the mundane administration of his empire, or threats that come from afar.
A flourishing empire cannot be threatened.
One must be prepared for the worst.

Bolívar watches idly as an admiral brandishes delicate instruments, explaining how they enable one to navigate the perilous oceans. Bolívar has always put the needs of his people first — of what use to them are lands that are half the world away?
There is only one way to find out.
Unfamiliar as these new lands may be, {1_STORY_CITY} already blossoms with potential. Perhaps there are kindred spirits among the locals.
Have a Settlement in Distant Lands.
Bolívar paces as his advisors bicker with one another. The meeting with the newly met leader was not a disaster, but some question the motives of those from across the vast oceans.
Let them be friends before they become enemies.
Ink dries on the contract as Bolívar grasps his counterpart's hand in assent. To know that one does not stand alone in this world is too great to ignore.
Form an Alliance with a Civilization in Distant Lands.
Visiting a barracks, Bolívar watches as veteran soldiers warn new recruits that obedience is the difference between life and death.
Once like arrows without a target, Bolívar's soldiers now take their purpose from their commander.
Soldiers should learn to think for themselves.
War has come to Simón Bolívar, but it was not unforeseen. He and his people stand as one against subjugation.
Bolívar's troops force the enemy to retreat, a welcome augur of victory. The war is not yet over, but the end may come sooner now.
Defeat an Army Commander in Distant Lands.
Bolívar strives to remain composed in the face of rejection — such insults reflect on him as well as on his people.
+1 War Support on all wars but a Building becomes Pillaged in {1_capital}.
Leadership always came naturally to Bolívar. He finds himself reluctant to trust in others he sees as unequipped for the challenges he faces.
There is a reason we have elites.
Try as he might, Simón Bolívar cannot put down his sword. Perhaps he only believes in freedom so long as he is the one to grant it.
The people will have to make sacrifices.
{1_reward} on all Units but 1 Building is Pillaged in all Settlements.
The troops will have to make sacrifices.
+3 War Support on all wars but 50 Damage to all Units.
It is such a simple thing, and yet for so long had eluded Bolívar — two nations engaged in productive relations, for the betterment of their own people and each other's.
Welcome the free exchange of ideas and capital.
Bolívar knows too well the desperation of fighting on one's own. So when a call for aid comes, he does not hesitate to answer.
Tell the world Bolívar is coming.
Bolívar's popularity with other leaders extends to their people — perhaps it is his way with words, perhaps his sheer force of personality.
They wish to see his lands for themselves.
They dedicate their lives to his cause.

The people of {1_STORY_CITY} cheer Simón Bolívar as the hero passes through its once war-torn streets. To gain the admiration of your enemy's people is a nigh impossible feat — unless you are el Libertador.
The merchants dream of greater prosperity.
The artisans plan their most ambitious projects.
Prosperity flows into Mexico on rivers of gold, a testament to the endurance and will of his people — and Simón Bolívar's wildest dreams brought to life.
Bolívar notices that the streets of {1_CAPITAL} have never been livelier. There is an opportunity here.
The promise of modernity belongs to all.
A great energy, unmistakeably {1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ}, courses along tracks that span Bolívar's empire. His people have never been more united.
From his earlest days, Bolívar has striven to stand behind his beliefs. Now, he asks his people to stand with him.
One after another, his enemies fall. Let others say what they will, but Simón Bolívar lives up to his convictions.
Have 5 Points in the Ideology Legacy Path.
As Bolivar, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +15% Gold, -10% Food
As Bolivar, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength towards Naval Units, -10% Influence
As Bolivar, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +15% Food, -10% Gold
As Bolivar, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength towards Air Units, -10% Influence
+5 Combat Strength for all Units against Districts.
+50% Gold towards converting a Town to a City.
[B]Simón Bolívar[/B] was influenced by the [B]French Empire[/B].
